thread.title: Peanut butter exec gets 28 years for salmonella outbreak
thread.title_full: Peanut butter exec gets 28 years for salmonella outbreak | News24

author: news24.com
title: Peanut butter exec gets 28 years for salmonella outbreak
text:
Albany - A former peanut company executive was sentenced on Monday to 28 years in prison for his role in a deadly salmonella outbreak, the stiffest punishment ever handed out to a producer in a foodborne illness case.
The outbreak in 2008 and 2009 was blamed for nine deaths and sickened hundreds more, and triggered one of the largest food recalls in US history.
Before he was sentenced, former Peanut Corporation of America owner Stewart Parnell listened as nine victims testified about the terror and grief caused by peanut butter traced to the company's plant in southwest Georgia. Hours later, they left the courthouse applauding the sentence.
Experts say the trial of Parnell and two co-defendants a year ago marked the first time US food producers stood trial on criminal charges in a food-poisoning case. The company went bankrupt following the salmonella outbreak.
